head.title: Journal of Great Bear Lake, 1805-1806. - Page #24

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #24 of 48 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: McKenzie, Alexander. Journal of Great Bear Lake, 1805-1806. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0006

div.p: I sent one of them Back with four of my men to acquaint his relations that we came to make friends with them and to trade with them[.] [I]n about fifty minuets the frenchmen returned with 30 men, woman & 3 Children[.] [T]hey Camped 10 pases from our Camp[.] [A]fter a few words passed they began to trade Beaver & martins – 188 Beaver[.] [T]hey was all well pleased with the Ironworks & Beads they reced for their furs[.]

12 Cannoes arrived from the oposite side of McKenzies River[,] 18 men[,] 8 Woman & 6 Children[.] [A]s soon as they debarked we fired two Gun, the report of which knocked down four of them[.] [A]s soon as all of them had drawn up their Cannoes they began to dance in advancing forward to my tent which lasted for one hour[.] [T]hen they began to abuse their relations for not having informed them of our arrival and suposed that it was for fear they would get goods as well as them. I informed them that I had plenty of goods[,] that the only thing that they wanted to get of them was Beaver for which I would give them any of my goods Except my Guns (they sid that they did not expect to get such valuable articles as that but hoped that the Eskimoes would not come now to attack them while I was there, that they would all fall in the watter as they sa me shoot a Gull & he fell in the watter and my dog went & brot him out[).] [T]hey requested to trade[.] I told them as soon as it would be done raining I would trade with them[.] [A]t 7 O Clock AM I traded their Peltries[.] Yakeban being the Greatest Raskall amongst them I made a Chief of him[.] I gave him a flag and informed him the use of it[.] I gave him a few articles gratis to encourage the others to work the Beaver viz. two flints[,] 1 awl[,] 1 fierstell & a piece of spunk – and that I would come to the same plase next spring to have all their peltries & provisions there[,] that if they was able to maintain a fort that they should have one[.] [T]hey said they was not able to hunt for a fort that they often wanted themselves[.]
I had the packs made up[.] [T]here is 7 small packs of 85 for very little value axes[,] Trenches & Beads[,] a few knives[.] [T]he Beads that is wanted for the Quarlers is Blue & white[.]

a 11 O Clock Embarked to return up the River as there was two bands or families a waiting for us to trade that we did not se Coming down. [M]y Indians informed me that there had been some white people destroyed by the Indians on the sea Coast – that the white men had got in

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
